1.0  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This document details how Columbus Foods complies with the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) requirements of the California Health and Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.  Compliance with EPA's Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68), Federal OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM), and Cal OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) is also be maintained. This plan has been developed specifically to address the requirements applicable to the use of anhydrous ammonia in a closed loop mechanical refrigeration system at Columbus Foods, 30977 San Antonio Street, Hayward, California.  Each of the following sections provides a general overview of the facility requirements and defines design attributes, documentation, and actions that are established to comply with those requirements.  Columbus Foods has already developed measures and systems that provide compliance with the CalARP rules as a result of meeting other regulatory program requirements.  This document does not replicate that information but rather provides cross-references to the applicable existing documentation.  In those instances where information was developed specifically to comply with the CalARP requirements, that information is contained in this document.  Note:  Columbus has rewritten and improved the company's CalARP/RMP/PSM programs.  All documentation prior to this effort is on-hand and available; all new programs/policies implemented as a result of this effort are initiated and are being utilized moving forward.

1.1.	Commitment to Safety

Columbus Foods is committed to providing all employees a work environment that is free from recognized health and safety hazards.  Accordingly, our goal is achieving and sustaining "Zero Accident Tolerance" through communication, information, and training.  We are dedicated to the concept that all employees receive the proper orientation and are provided with the means necessary to ensure the

environment remains as safe and healthful as possible.

1.1.1.	It is the policy of Columbus Foods to: 

1.1.1.1	Provide safe working conditions, proper tools, and personal protective equipment.

1.1.1.2	Comply with all federal, state, and local occupational health and safety laws and regulations.

1.1.1.3	Ensure through training, and when necessary disciplinary action, that all employees work in a safe manner.

 
1.1.1.4	Educate and/or train all employees in safe work practices, and ensure that each employee fully understands their job, equipment, techniques, and methods to reduce the risk to themselves and their co-workers.

1.1.2.	Encourage all employees to "Think Safety", so that safety habits developed and practiced at work carry through to non-work related activities.

1.1.3.	Columbus Foods' aim is to provide high quality products as efficiently as possible while minimizing the use of toxic materials whereever possible.  Where hazardous toxics cannot be eliminated, engineering/administrative controls to handle these substances will be implemented.

1.1.4.	Columbus Foods has prepared a safety policy and procedures program specifically tailored for the facility in addition to establishing a Process Safety Management Program.  It is the responsibility of the facility's management to carry out these programs.

1.1.5.	The first duty of Columbus Foods employees is to exercise care in the performance of their work tasks to prevent an accident to themselves, co-workers, the general public or equipment.  Safety-consciousness must take precedence over expedience, and is required as a condition of continued employment of all employees at all levels of the organization.

1.2.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

1.2.1.	Columbus will make all reasonable efforts to continually monitor and improve the safety of its systems.

1.2.2.	Regulatory program implementation will facilitate follow-up items from the following activities: Process Hazard Analyses, Seismic Studies, Incident

Investigations, Operating Procedure Reviews, and Compliance Audits.  Columbus is committed to implementing the recommendations from these activities as a way of always improving safety.
 
1.2.3.	In addition, more dramatic system changes such as alternate refrigerants (i.e.: expanded use of glycol), better confinement of ammonia charge, advanced detection and alarming, and public notification are always being investigated.  If appropriate, future changes to improve safety will be implemented.


1.3.	Columbus Foods Description

1.3.1.	Columbus Foods is located at 30977 San Antonio Street, Hayward, California. The facility is a salame and deli meat slicing facility that receives work in progress from other facilities. The work in progress is sliced and packaged on site to make final products for distribution. 

1.3.2.	Anhydrous ammonia, which is regulated under CalARP, is utilized at Columbus Foods in the facility's ammonia refrigeration system. The ammonia is contained in various vessels, piping, evaporators, condensers, compressors and miscellaneous refrigeration equipment located throughout the refrigeration system.  The system is a single stage, critically charged system.  The system has two screw compressors, two condensers, one high pressure receiver and one high temperature receiver with two pumps that supplies recirculated ammonia liquid to 12 evaporators and a plate and frame heat exchanger.  Liquid refrigerant supplied to the evaporator units and heat exchanger absorbs heat energy from the surrounding air, the addition of heat energy to the refrigerant causes a change in density.  The less dense refrigerant returns to the high temp receiver where it separates with the vapor being drawn off into the high stage suction header.  The compressors maintain a constant suction pressure in the header.

1.3.3.	As a result of the use of anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant at Columbus Foods, the facility has developed and implemented a Level 3 Prevention Program in accord

ance with CalARP 2760 and 40 CFR 68.  Also in place is a Process Safety Management program as required by Cal OSHA Title 8, Section 5189 and OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.119. A Management System has been developed to oversee the regulatory programs at the Columbus Foods facility.   

1.4.	Worst/Alternate Case Release Scenarios

1.4.1.	Although engineering controls incorporated into the refrigeration process would normally prevent such releases, the possibility of a "catastrophic release" does exist.  Based on that premise, the facility has modeled two off site consequence analyses; one worst case scenario, and one alternate case scenario. Scenario documentation is on file at the San Antonio facility.

1.4.2.	For all scenarios, EPA's RMP Comp (Revision 1.07) modeling software was used to determine Off-Site Consequence Analyses.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for such a release and potential receptors are discussed in Section 3.2 and shown on maps in Appendix B of this document.

1.5.	Emergency Response Program

1.5.1.	Columbus Foods is equipped with emergency warning systems.  Alarms (both visual and auditory) are strategically placed throughout the facility to alarm personnel of an emergency relating to the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or other emergencies that may be encountered.  There are specific procedures that all employees will follow in the event of release, which can be found in the facility Emergency Response Plan on file and located with other critical regulatory program documentation. These procedures include appropriate notification and evacuation of facility personnel.

1.5.2.	In the event that an ammonia release or spill does occur, off-site responders, specifically the Hayward Fire Department and the Alameda County LEPC, and immediate neighboring facilities will be notified.
